thread.title: ‘Not for mine’: Cats T-shirts divide AFL world
thread.title_full: ‘Not for mine’: Cats T-shirts divide AFL world

title: ‘Not for mine’: Cats T-shirts divide AFL world
text:
Geelong unveils new T-shirt playing strip for 2017 JLT Community Series against Hawthorn February 17, 2017 8:49pm by Staff Writers Source: FOX SPORTS AT FIRST glance, you’d be excused for thinking Hawthorn had gatecrashed a Geelong training session when the Cats graced the University of Tasmania Stadium turf on Friday night. 
But nope, this was for real. 
The Cats unveiled their new — and very unique — pre-season playing strip for 2017 in Launceston on Friday night. 
As part of the Cats’ new apparel partnership with Cotton On, they donned an AFL-first “rugby-styled” jumper, which was a skin-tight T-shirt with a V-neck cut. 
A few traditional blue hoops were printed across the chest, but the most notable aspect of the jumper was the capital G plastered across the torso. 
Western Bulldogs legend Brad Johnson, who spent a few weeks coaching the Cats over the summer, said he was a fan of the new look. 
“I like them, I think they look very good,” Johnson told Fox Footy . Patrick Dangerfield in Geelong’s new-look jumper. Source: Getty Images 
“They’ve got a new sponsor in Cotton On for their active range, so it’s great they’ve jumped on board.” 
Hawthorn champion Dermott Brereton, however, wasn’t so impressed. 
“I like symmetry in the jumper. A ‘G’ doesn’t have many symmetrical notions,” Brereton said. 
“Sorry, not for mine.” 
But Fox Footy caller Dwayne Russell, who played 50 VFL games in the blue and white hoops, was in Johnson’s corner. 
“If you’re a 45-year-old, you’re not going to be walking the streets in a footy jumper. But you might wear a T-shirt,” Russell said. 
“I like it, you can wear it around the streets and it’s not too crazy.” 
Live stream EVERY game of the JLT Community Series on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW > 
Geelong’s decision to go down the T-shirt path mirrors what many NBA teams are now doing, switching between traditional singlets and sleeved jerseys. 
The footy world also had its say via social media. Geelong tshirts. No. — Al Paton (@al_superfooty) February 17, 2017 Dear Geelong. Warm up is over. — Daniel Cherny 📰 (@DanielCherny) February 17, 2017 Geelong's top may not be the worst thing ever but they've tried. #JLTSeries — Titus O'Reily (@TitusOReily) February 17, 2017 If you thought this Cats jumper was bad...In 2000, Hawthorn wore this in the pre-season. #JLTSeries pic.twitter.com/KzL5ZKQP0M — William Hill Aus (@WillHillAus) February 17, 2017
